thread.title: The show goes on, for now, at Huntington Playhouse
thread.title_full: The show goes on, for now, at Huntington Playhouse | cleveland.com

author: Tom Feran, The Plain Dealer
title: The show goes on, for now, at Huntington Playhouse
text:
BAY VILLAGE, Ohio -- The show went on Saturday night at the Huntington Playhouse , as theater tradition says it must, but the prospect of a final curtain for the volunteer company made a troubling backdrop for its patrons.
They reacted with sadness and sometimes anger at the announced closing of the 57-year-old theater.
"It's sad," said Marge Taress of Avon Lake, who joined a ticket line that extended out the door a half hour before showtime. "I like community theater, and this one has been around for a long time."
"I'm disappointed," said Bob Czajkowski of Olmsted Falls. "We come here regularly."
The Cleveland Metroparks announced Friday that it will not renew its agreement with the playhouse, which is in the park system's Huntington Reservation but is operated by a private nonprofit organization.
Park officials cited safety concerns and unpaid bills for the decision to close the operation when the current season ends in December.
Tom Meyrose, the playhouse's executive director, took the stage before the start of Saturday's performance of "My Way: A Musical Tribute to Frank Sinatra."
"We've had a couple of setbacks," he told the audience. "We've had a few problems with our water system" that he said flooded the stage and dressing rooms.
But he made no mention of a final closing in his warmly received remarks, and focused instead on coming productions : the comedy "Death by Design," running Sept. 17 to Oct. 11, "The Addams Family," Oct. 22 to Nov. 15, and a holiday show Dec. 3-20.
"The Addams Family" has shows both Halloween and Friday the 13th, he said -- "You can't beat that with a stick!
"Please tell your friends. We rely on word of mouth," Meyrose added, noting that building public awareness is a particular problem of community theater.
The audience filled a respectable two-thirds of the comfortably rustic 240-seat theater. They ranged from first-timers to regulars of more than 40 years.
"It saddens my heart" that the current season could be the last, said a woman from North Royalton who has been coming for years. "I think it's terrible."
More information: huntingtonplayhouse.org .
